title: Tinker
data:
**Tinker** is a [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM").

All [gnomes](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)") obtain the technique at [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 7.

## Description

To use the technique, you must not be [blinded](/wiki/Blind "Blind") and [wield](/wiki/Wield "Wield") an applicable object - see [upgrading objects](/wiki/Upgrading_objects "Upgrading objects") for a list of eligible items. When used, you will become [occupied](/wiki/Occupation "Occupation") until you either complete the technique (which takes \[150-technique level] turns) or you are interrupted; there is no specific cooldown afterward, though you will fail to upgrade the object if you are interrupted. The chances of actually upgrading an object after finishing the technique without interruption are dependent on [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck").

Using the tinker technique does not break any [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct"), such as [polypileless](/wiki/Polypileless "Polypileless"). Items produced will have the same enchantment and [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude") status as the original item.

## Strategy

The tinker technique grants gnomes much earlier access to many common ascension kit items while preserving conducts and saving several [wishes](/wiki/Wish "Wish"). Below is a list of common candidates and the items you can tinker with to obtain them:

- The [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") can be obtained by tinkering with an [elven cloak](/wiki/Elven_cloak "Elven cloak") or an [oilskin cloak](/wiki/Oilskin_cloak "Oilskin cloak"), with a 1⁄4 chance. [Dwarvish](/wiki/Dwarvish_cloak "Dwarvish cloak") and [orcish cloaks](/wiki/Orcish_cloak "Orcish cloak") can always be upgraded to elven or oilskin cloaks.
- An oilskin cloak can be obtained with a 1⁄2 chance from upgrading any of the following cloaks: magic resistance, [protection](/wiki/Cloak_of_protection "Cloak of protection"), [displacement](/wiki/Cloak_of_displacement "Cloak of displacement"), [invisiblity](/wiki/Cloak_of_invisibility "Cloak of invisibility"), dwarvish, or orcish. You can safely enchant an elven cloak to +7 before upgrading it into an oilskin cloak or cloak of magic resistance.
- [Gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity") can be obtained with a 1⁄2 chance from upgrading [leather gloves](/wiki/Leather_gloves "Leather gloves").
- A [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding") can be obtained with a 1⁄5 chance from upgrading a [sack](/wiki/Sack "Sack"), and the remainder of the time you will get an [oilskin sack](/wiki/Oilskin_sack "Oilskin sack"), which always becomes a bag of holding when upgraded.
- Upgrading a [dwarvish iron helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_iron_helm "Dwarvish iron helm") will produce either a [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance") or a [helm of telepathy](/wiki/Helm_of_telepathy "Helm of telepathy"), with an equal probability for each. An [orcish helm](/wiki/Orcish_helm "Orcish helm") can always be upgraded to a dwarvish iron helm.
- An ordinary [robe](/wiki/Robe_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Robe (SLASH'EM)") can be upgraded into a [robe of power](/wiki/Robe_of_power "Robe of power") with a 1⁄2 chance.

Gnomes with an early [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") should take this technique into consideration when choosing what to wish for: for gnomes that settle on [dragon scale mail](/wiki/Dragon_scale_mail "Dragon scale mail") the ability to 'guarantee' a cloak of magic resistance makes [silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail") a much better [first wish](/wiki/GDSM_versus_SDSM "GDSM versus SDSM") for them.

All upgraded items can be "upgraded" again to a previous form, which is useful for items where the desired result is not guaranteed: as an example, if you upgrade leather gloves and produce [gauntlets of swimming](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_swimming "Gauntlets of swimming") rather than gauntlets of dexterity, you can then "upgrade" those gauntlets of swimming back to leather gloves, and try again. In essence, you will only ever need one of the base item - this also means that even with high Luck, many of the above upgrades will require multiple attempts, whether to obtain a specific desired item or complete a multi-step chain leading to one.

Since tinkering may require multiple tries to obtain a given item, ensure that you will not be interrupted before you can complete your occupation, e.g. by a hostile monster coming into view - you will generally want to lock yourself in a small room with a stockpile of food if upgrading multiple items this way. An early [ring of slow digestion](/wiki/Ring_of_slow_digestion "Ring of slow digestion") is quite useful to this end if you happen across one.

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
Tinker

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Tinker is a technique that appears in SLASH'EM, SlashTHEM and Hack'EM.

All gnomes obtain the technique at experience level 7.

Description

To use the technique, you must not be blinded and wield an applicable object - see upgrading objects for a list of eligible items. When used, you will become occupied until you either complete the technique (which takes [150-technique level] turns) or you are interrupted; there is no specific cooldown afterward, though you will fail to upgrade the object if you are interrupted. The chances of actually upgrading an object after finishing the technique without interruption are dependent on Luck.

Using the tinker technique does not break any conduct, such as polypileless. Items produced will have the same enchantment and beatitude status as the original item.

Strategy

The tinker technique grants gnomes much earlier access to many common ascension kit items while preserving conducts and saving several wishes. Below is a list of common candidates and the items you can tinker with to obtain them:

  • The cloak of magic resistance can be obtained by tinkering with an elven cloak or an oilskin cloak, with a 1⁄4 chance. Dwarvish and orcish cloaks can always be upgraded to elven or oilskin cloaks.
  • An oilskin cloak can be obtained with a 1⁄2 chance from upgrading any of the following cloaks: magic resistance, protection, displacement, invisiblity, dwarvish, or orcish. You can safely enchant an elven cloak to +7 before upgrading it into an oilskin cloak or cloak of magic resistance.
  • Gauntlets of dexterity can be obtained with a 1⁄2 chance from upgrading leather gloves.
  • A bag of holding can be obtained with a 1⁄5 chance from upgrading a sack, and the remainder of the time you will get an oilskin sack, which always becomes a bag of holding when upgraded.
  • Upgrading a dwarvish iron helm will produce either a helm of brilliance or a helm of telepathy, with an equal probability for each. An orcish helm can always be upgraded to a dwarvish iron helm.
  • An ordinary robe can be upgraded into a robe of power with a 1⁄2 chance.

Gnomes with an early wish should take this technique into consideration when choosing what to wish for: for gnomes that settle on dragon scale mail the ability to 'guarantee' a cloak of magic resistance makes silver dragon scale mail a much better first wish for them.

All upgraded items can be "upgraded" again to a previous form, which is useful for items where the desired result is not guaranteed: as an example, if you upgrade leather gloves and produce gauntlets of swimming rather than gauntlets of dexterity, you can then "upgrade" those gauntlets of swimming back to leather gloves, and try again. In essence, you will only ever need one of the base item - this also means that even with high Luck, many of the above upgrades will require multiple attempts, whether to obtain a specific desired item or complete a multi-step chain leading to one.

Since tinkering may require multiple tries to obtain a given item, ensure that you will not be interrupted before you can complete your occupation, e.g. by a hostile monster coming into view - you will generally want to lock yourself in a small room with a stockpile of food if upgrading multiple items this way. An early ring of slow digestion is quite useful to this end if you happen across one.

Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Tinker&oldid=152189"

'''Tinker''' is a [[technique]] that appears in [[SLASH'EM]], [[SlashTHEM]] and [[Hack'EM]].

All [[Gnome (starting race)|gnomes]] obtain the technique at [[experience level]] 7.

==Description==
To use the technique, you must not be [[blind]]ed and [[wield]] an applicable object - see [[upgrading objects]] for a list of eligible items. When used, you will become [[occupation|occupied]] until you either complete the technique (which takes [150-technique level] turns) or you are interrupted; there is no specific cooldown afterward, though you will fail to upgrade the object if you are interrupted. The chances of actually upgrading an object after finishing the technique without interruption are dependent on [[Luck]].

Using the tinker technique does not break any [[conduct]], such as [[polypileless]]. Items produced will have the same enchantment and [[beatitude]] status as the original item.

==Strategy==
The tinker technique grants gnomes much earlier access to many common ascension kit items while preserving conducts and saving several [[wish]]es. Below is a list of common candidates and the items you can tinker with to obtain them: 

* The [[cloak of magic resistance]] can be obtained by tinkering with an [[elven cloak]] or an [[oilskin cloak]], with a {{frac|4}} chance. [[Dwarvish cloak|Dwarvish]] and [[orcish cloak]]s can always be upgraded to elven or oilskin cloaks.
* An oilskin cloak can be obtained with a {{frac|2}} chance from upgrading any of the following cloaks: magic resistance, [[cloak of protection|protection]], [[cloak of displacement|displacement]], [[cloak of invisibility|invisiblity]], dwarvish, or orcish. You can safely enchant an elven cloak to +7 before upgrading it into an oilskin cloak or cloak of magic resistance.
* [[Gauntlets of dexterity]] can be obtained with a {{frac|2}} chance from upgrading [[leather gloves]].
* A [[bag of holding]] can be obtained with a {{frac|5}} chance from upgrading a [[sack]], and the remainder of the time you will get an [[oilskin sack]], which always becomes a bag of holding when upgraded.
* Upgrading a [[dwarvish iron helm]] will produce either a [[helm of brilliance]] or a [[helm of telepathy]], with an equal probability for each. An [[orcish helm]] can always be upgraded to a dwarvish iron helm.
* An ordinary [[Robe (SLASH'EM)|robe]] can be upgraded into a [[robe of power]] with a {{frac|2}} chance.

Gnomes with an early [[wish]] should take this technique into consideration when choosing what to wish for: for gnomes that settle on [[dragon scale mail]] the ability to 'guarantee' a cloak of magic resistance makes [[silver dragon scale mail]] a much better [[GDSM versus SDSM|first wish]] for them.

All upgraded items can be "upgraded" again to a previous form, which is useful for items where the desired result is not guaranteed: as an example, if you upgrade leather gloves and produce [[gauntlets of swimming]] rather than gauntlets of dexterity, you can then "upgrade" those gauntlets of swimming back to leather gloves, and try again. In essence, you will only ever need one of the base item - this also means that even with high Luck, many of the above upgrades will require multiple attempts, whether to obtain a specific desired item or complete a multi-step chain leading to one.

Since tinkering may require multiple tries to obtain a given item, ensure that you will not be interrupted before you can complete your occupation, e.g. by a hostile monster coming into view - you will generally want to lock yourself in a small room with a stockpile of food if upgrading multiple items this way. An early [[ring of slow digestion]] is quite useful to this end if you happen across one.
